DOM Manipulation ‚Äì Complete Guide

What is DOM?

The Document Object Model (DOM) is a programming interface for web documents. It represents the page as a structured tree of objects that can be manipulated with JavaScript.

  • Every HTML element becomes a node in this tree.
  • You can add, remove, or modify these elements using JavaScript.

DOM Access Methods

  • document.getElementById(id)
  • document.getElementsByClassName(class)
  • document.getElementsByTagName(tag)
  • document.querySelector(selector)
  • document.querySelectorAll(selector)

Node Properties

  • node.innerHTML: Get/set HTML content
  • node.textContent: Get/set text content
  • node.innerText: Similar to textContent but respects CSS styles
  • node.nodeType: Type of the node (1 = Element, 3 = Text, etc.)
  • node.nodeName: Name of the node (e.g., DIV, SPAN)

Traversing the DOM

  • parentNode, childNodes, firstChild, lastChild
  • children, firstElementChild, lastElementChild
  • nextSibling, previousSibling, nextElementSibling

Creating and Modifying Elements

  • document.createElement("tag")
  • node.appendChild(child)
  • node.insertBefore(newNode, referenceNode)
  • node.replaceChild(newNode, oldNode)
  • node.removeChild(child)

Attributes Manipulation

  • element.setAttribute("attr", "value")
  • element.getAttribute("attr")
  • element.removeAttribute("attr")
  • Also accessible directly like: element.id, element.href, etc.

Class Manipulation

  • element.classList.add("class")
  • element.classList.remove("class")
  • element.classList.toggle("class")
  • element.classList.contains("class")

Style Manipulation

  • element.style.property (e.g., element.style.color = "red")
  • To access computed styles: window.getComputedStyle(element)

Event Handling

  • element.addEventListener("event", callback)
  • element.removeEventListener("event", callback)
  • Common events: click, mouseover, keydown, submit

Event Object Properties:

  • event.target, event.currentTarget
  • event.preventDefault(), event.stopPropagation()

Event Delegation

Attaching one event listener to a parent element to handle events from children using event.target. Efficient for dynamically added elements.

Forms & Input

  • Access form: document.forms["formName"]
  • Input values: inputElement.value
  • Radio/Checkbox: element.checked
  • Submit forms: form.submit()

Advanced Techniques

  • MutationObserver: Watch for changes in the DOM
  • Shadow DOM: Encapsulation inside web components
  • template & slot: Declarative DOM fragments in HTML5

Performance Tips

  • Use documentFragment when adding multiple elements
  • Avoid layout thrashing (multiple reads & writes)
  • Debounce expensive event listeners (scroll, resize)

Best Practices

  • Use const / let for variables
  • Keep selectors scoped to minimize DOM search time
  • Use semantic HTML and avoid deeply nested DOMs
  • Clean up listeners to avoid memory leaks

Live Example


      const btn = document.querySelector("#clickMe");
      btn.addEventListener("click", () => {
        const newDiv = document.createElement("div");
        newDiv.textContent = "You clicked!";
        document.body.appendChild(newDiv);
      });

Debugging Tips

  • Use console.log() to inspect elements and events
  • Inspect elements with browser DevTools
  • Use breakpoints to pause code execution

üìå JavaScript Event Listeners ‚Äì Complete Breakdown

Event listeners allow JavaScript to "listen" for interactions or changes in the DOM. They enable dynamic, interactive websites.

MDN Docs: addEventListener()

üß† Syntax:


      element.addEventListener("eventType", callbackFunction, useCapture);
  • eventType: A string like "click", "keydown", "submit"
  • callbackFunction: Function to run when the event fires
  • useCapture (optional): Boolean for event phase (true = capture, false = bubbling)

üõ†Ô∏è Commonly Used Events & Examples:

1. Click Event


      document.querySelector("#btn").addEventListener("click", function() {
        alert("Button Clicked!");
      });

2. Mouse Events

  • mouseover, mouseout, mousemove, mousedown, mouseup, dblclick

      element.addEventListener("mouseover", () => {
        element.style.backgroundColor = "yellow";
      });

3. Keyboard Events

  • keydown, keypress, keyup

      document.addEventListener("keydown", function(e) {
        console.log("Key pressed:", e.key);
      });

4. Form Events

  • submit, change, input, focus, blur

      document.querySelector("form").addEventListener("submit", function(e) {
        e.preventDefault(); // Prevents actual submission
        alert("Form submitted!");
      });

5. Window Events

  • load, resize, scroll, beforeunload

      window.addEventListener("resize", () =$gt; {
        console.log("Window resized!");
      });

6. Touch Events (Mobile)

  • touchstart, touchmove, touchend

7. Custom Events


      const myEvent = new Event("customEvent");
      element.addEventListener("customEvent", () =$gt; console.log("Custom event fired!"));
      element.dispatchEvent(myEvent);

üìå Event Object

The callback function receives an event object with useful properties:

  • event.type ‚Äì Event name
  • event.target ‚Äì The element that triggered the event
  • event.currentTarget ‚Äì The element the listener is attached to
  • event.preventDefault() ‚Äì Stops default action (e.g., form submit)
  • event.stopPropagation() ‚Äì Stops event bubbling

üß≠ Event Flow (Capture vs. Bubbling)

Events travel in three phases:

  1. Capture phase ‚Äì Down the DOM tree
  2. Target phase ‚Äì Event reaches target
  3. Bubbling phase ‚Äì Bubbles back up the DOM tree (default)

To handle capturing:


      element.addEventListener("click", handler, true); // capture = true

üßπ Removing Event Listeners


      function logClick() {
        console.log("Clicked");
      }
      element.addEventListener("click", logClick);
      element.removeEventListener("click", logClick);

Note: You must reference the same function to remove it!

üöÄ Event Delegation

Attach a single listener to a parent and use event.target to handle child interactions.


      document.querySelector("#list").addEventListener("click", function(e) {
        if (e.target.tagName === "LI") {
          console.log("Clicked:", e.target.textContent);
        }
      });

‚úÖ Efficient for dynamic elements!

üìö More MDN Event Reference

  • Complete List of DOM Events
  • Event Object Details
  • EventTarget Interface

‚úÖ Best Practices

  • Use const for named event handler functions
  • Always remove listeners on cleanup (especially in SPA or React)
  • Delegate for lists and tables with many children
  • Throttle or debounce heavy events (scroll, resize)
